Comments_List: I've learnt a broad range of topics on most recent developments in cluster algebras

I learned about a more recent development in mathematics that brings together algebraic geometry, geometric topology, and representation theory.  I had to learn a lot of material along the way (before I had almost no experience with Teichmuller theory).

It is a demanding course and the lectures were at a high level, especially those explaining the Gross-Hacking-Keel-Kontsevich paper.  One thing that I regret is not learning about cluster tilting theory; my original interest in signing up for the course was to see how it interacted with tilting in the representation theory of associative algebras.
While I doubt this precise course will be offered in the future, this seminar-style course is both demanding and very different from a usual class.
